diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, kidneys, and joints. Malar rash, nephritis, and synovitis are hallmark features.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease with overlapping features of SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including skin rash, joint inflammation, and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease known for its distinctive skin rash and muscle weakness. While less common, it can also affect the joints and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting joints, but extra-articular manifestations can include skin lesions and renal involvement in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease causing hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. Kidney involvement and joint symptoms can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands. Though rare, it can be associated with kidney disease and skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause skin rashes, kidney dysfunction, and joint pain among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the kidneys caused by SLE. It is not a separate diagnosis but a significant complication of lupus.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can cause blood clots, miscarriages, and skin ulcers. It is often associated with SLE.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the heart's inner lining or the heart valves. It can cause skin manifestations, joint pain, and in severe cases, can affect the kidneys.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Dengue fever, Ebola virus disease)
Lupus nephritis (as part of SLE spectrum)
Epilepsy (secondary to CNS involvement in systemic diseases)
Vitamin deficiency (specifically vitamins B12, C, K)
Connective tissue diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Sexually transmitted infections causing vaginitis (e.g., gonorrhea, chlamydia)
Non-sexually transmitted infections causing vaginitis (e.g., bacterial vaginosis, yeast infection)

diagnoses.reason: Directly matches the symptom of obsessive-compulsive behavior.
Patients with anxiety can exhibit obsessive-compulsive behaviors, sometimes experience tinnitus due to stress, and may have stress-related nosebleeds (epistaxis).
Depression can lead to psychosomatic symptoms such as tinnitus and exacerbate or contribute to obsessive-compulsive behaviors.
Can cause or exacerbate depression and anxiety, leading to obsessive-compulsive behaviors. Also, hypothyroidism can lead to hypothermia.
Can cause tinnitus and epistaxis. Severe cases might contribute to hypothermia.
May cause epistaxis due to coagulopathy, hemorrhoids due to portal hypertension, and can be associated with metabolic imbalances affecting mood and cognitive function.
Can be a contributing factor to hemorrhoids and tinnitus.
Directly related to the development of hemorrhoids.
Can cause tinnitus, lead to episodes of hypothermia due to dysregulation of the autonomic nervous system, and may have comorbid anxiety or depression influencing obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

Certain conditions like Tourette syndrome may present with tics that can be confused with obsessive-compulsive behaviors, and neurological issues can cause or contribute to the other symptoms through various mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. Symptoms often include fatigue, skin rashes, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms may include fatigue, pain, balance issues, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by tick bites. Symptoms can include fatigue, headache, fever, and skin rashes. If untreated, it may lead to joint pain and neurological problems.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition. Fatigue may worsen with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition in which mast cells inappropriately release excessive chemical mediators, leading to a range of chronic symptoms, including episodic weakness, migratory abdominal pain, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus weakens your immune system by destroying important cells that fight disease and infection. Symptoms can include fatigue, night sweats, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where stomach contents come back up into the esophagus resulting in either symptoms or complications. Symptoms include burning pain in the chest, nausea, and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: An intestinal disorder causing pain in the belly, gas, diarrhea, and constipation. IBS can cause episodic abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental illnesses that cause constant and overwhelming anxiety and fear. Symptoms can include fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and muscle tension.

diagnoses.name: Viral infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common viral infections can cause abnormal liver enzymes, laryngitis, and lymphadenitis as part of systemic involvement. Anxiety and POTS can be associated or exacerbated by systemic illness.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus)
diagnoses.reasoning: Known for causing fever, sore throat (laryngitis), swollen lymph glands (lymphadenitis), and can affect the liver causing abnormal liver enzymes. POTS and anxiety can be secondary symptoms due to the body's response to the virus.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune disorders, like lupus or Sjögren's syndrome, can cause a broad range of symptoms including those affecting the liver, lymphatic system, and causing POTS; anxiety might be related to the illness or its management.

diagnoses.name: Lyme disease
diagnoses.reasoning: A tick-borne illness that can cause a wide array of symptoms including abnormal liver enzymes, lymphadenitis, and neurological symptoms that might manifest as anxiety or POTS.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Inflammation of the liver, whether from viral causes (A, B, C), alcohol, or other toxins, can cause abnormal liver enzymes. The systemic nature of the illness could potentially play a role in triggering POTS and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: HIV infection
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV can cause a multitude of symptoms including lymphadenitis, abnormal liver enzymes due to the infection itself or associated medications, and can have neurological effects that might contribute to POTS and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Alcohol-related liver disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic alcohol use can lead to elevated liver enzymes and can have systemic effects that may indirectly contribute to symptoms like POTS and anxiety, although less directly associated with lymphadenitis and laryngitis unless there's a concurrent infection.

diagnoses.name: Toxic substance exposure
diagnoses.reasoning: Exposure to certain toxins can cause liver enzyme abnormalities and directly or indirectly contribute to the other symptoms listed through systemic toxicity or immune response.

diagnoses.name: Post-viral syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Following an acute viral infection, individuals may experience a range of ongoing symptoms including fatigue, POTS, anxiety, and liver enzyme elevations as part of a post-viral syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain cancers, especially those involving the liver, lymphatic system, or with systemic involvement, can cause a wide range of symptoms including abnormal liver enzymes, lymphadenitis, anxiety, and even POTS through various mechanisms.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Thrombocytosis is common in CML due to increased production of blood cells. Difficulty focusing vision and irritated eyes could be related to increased blood cell counts causing microcirculation problems. Lymphadenopathy may occur due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

diagnoses.description: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Though thrombocytosis is less common in acute leukemia, lymphadenopathy is a characteristic feature. Vision changes and eye irritation could stem from infiltration of leukemic cells or from systemic symptoms like anemia.

diagnoses.description: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: This myeloproliferative disorder can cause thrombocytosis and is associated with vision problems and headaches, indicating possible difficulties with concentrating. Lymphadenopathy is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.description: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can cause a wide range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy and eye irritation (e.g., Sjögren’s syndrome). Cognitive dysfunction like difficulty in concentrating is known as 'lupus fog'.

diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Sarcoidosis involves the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of your body, including the eyes and lymph nodes, which can lead to symptoms such as irritated eyes, lymphadenopathy, and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV can cause lymphadenopathy and eye irritation, with neurocognitive disorders affecting concentration. Thrombocytosis can sometimes be seen in chronic infection stages.

diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: TB can cause lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms might include thrombocytosis. Eye involvement (e.g., uveitis) can cause vision problems and irritation. Cognitive symptoms could relate to systemic illness.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: While not classically presenting with thrombocytosis (more often thrombocytopenia), it can cause increased blood viscosity affecting vision and concentration. Lymphadenopathy is rare but can occur in extramedullary myeloma.

diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: RA can be associated with secondary Sjogren's syndrome, leading to dry and irritated eyes. Lymphadenopathy can occur, and chronic inflammation can contribute to cognitive difficulties.

diagnoses.description: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Lyme disease can cause a variety of symptoms including lymphadenopathy, eye irritation, and cognitive disruptions such as difficulty concentrating. Thrombocytosis is not typical but can occur in the context of systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may lead to symptoms like chronic back pain and can indirectly cause dysautonomias due to its effects on the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, Sjögren's Syndrome can also cause chronic pain, including back pain, and may have implications related to dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic back pain. Though less directly, it could be associated with chest pain due to inflammation of the chest wall and joints between the ribs and vertebrae.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. MS can cause a wide range of symptoms, including dysautonomias, chronic pain, and could potentially be linked to symptoms like dry eyes through associated autoimmune reactions.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms can vary widely but can include chest pain, chronic back pain, and dry eyes.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can affect more than just your joints. In some people, the condition can damage a wide variety of body systems, including the skin, eyes, lungs, heart and blood vessels. It may manifest as chronic back pain and can have associations with dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Osteoarthritis
diagnoses.description: The most common form of arthritis, affecting millions of people worldwide. It occurs when the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of your bones wears down over time. While it typically affects the hands, knees, hips, and spine, chronic back pain is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Degenerative Disc Disease
diagnoses.description: This condition refers to a disease in which pain is caused from a damaged disc in the spine leading to chronic back pain. Chest pain may also occur in severe cases due to associated spinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Costochondritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the sternum (breastbone). It can cause chest pain that may be mistaken for a heart attack. It could co-occur with conditions like fibromyalgia, affecting the back and potentially aligned with dysautonomias symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Myofascial Pain Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chronic pain disorder in which pressure on sensitive points in your muscles (trigger points) causes pain in seemingly unrelated parts of your body. This can include chronic back pain and potentially affect other conditions such as dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often accompanies other immune system disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. It involves the destruction of glands that produce tears and saliva. Symptoms may include oral pain due to dry mouth, difficulty focusing vision because of dry eyes, and potential involvement in hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to hypothyroidism, or underactive thyroid, which can cause oral pain due to salivary gland enlargement, difficulty focusing, and other systemic issues like infertility.

diagnoses.name: Iron Overload (Hemochromatosis)
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when too much iron builds up in the body over many years, leading to hyperferritinemia. It can cause a variety of symptoms including joint pain, fatigue, and in some cases, hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. While not directly associated with oral pain or hypothyroidism, it can cause infertility and is often correlated with other systemic symptoms and conditions.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. It can cause complications such as gum disease (leading to oral pain), vision problems, and has been linked with hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can lead to difficulties focusing vision due to muscle fatigue. It is also associated with thyroid disorders.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism), but can also be associated with ophthalmopathy causing vision focusing difficulties. Patients with autoimmune thyroid conditions can also experience reproductive issues.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While directly causing oral pain is less common, it can be associated with Sjögren's syndrome, which does affect the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can lead to a variety of symptoms, including vision problems and, in some cases, thyroid disorders.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including neurological problems that affect vision, and potentially mimic some thyroid disorders.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Sensory neuropathies and dyslipidemia are common complications.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by sensory and motor neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to sensory neuropathies and can contribute to muscle pain due to associated anemia.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause dyslipidemia, muscle pain, and neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Associated with muscle pain, headache, and can coexist with chronic conditions like dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic bronchitis is a major contributor; might indirectly affect muscle pain due to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to dyslipidemia and sensory neuropathies due to toxin build-up.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.reasoning: Systemic lupus erythematosus could cause widespread symptoms including neuropathies, muscle pain, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Autoimmune disease that can lead to neuropathy and has associations with dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: While less commonly linked to dyslipidemia, can cause sensory neuropathies and muscle pain.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Vitamin deficiency (Vitamin C, Vitamin K, Vitamin B12)
Side effects of medications or drug interactions

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Monocytosis can often be a response to viral infections, which can also explain generalized symptoms like chest pain and difficulty focusing vision due to fatigue or fever.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Symptoms like difficulty focusing and chronic pain (including chest pain and conditions like interstitial cystitis) can be indicative of chronic fatigue syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorder
diagnoses.reasoning: Many autoimmune disorders can present with a wide range of symptoms including chest pain (potentially from pericarditis), vision problems, urinary issues like interstitial cystitis, and sinusitis. Monocytosis is an immune response that could be related.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Interstitial cystitis, monocytosis, difficulty focusing, and fatigue-related symptoms like chest pain can sometimes be associated with Lyme disease, especially in later stages.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Interstitial cystitis and widespread pain, including chest pain, alongside chronic fatigue, can point to fibromyalgia. Sinusitis and vision problems might be comorbid conditions rather than direct symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.reasoning: While predominantly a sinus issue, chronic sinusitis can lead to systemic symptoms such as fatigue, which may cause chest pain, focus problems, and might be linked to chronic pain conditions like interstitial cystitis due to overall inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands. It can lead to systemic symptoms including vision problems, and potentially interstitial cystitis and chest pain due to associated conditions.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can present with a variety of symptoms, including vision difficulties and chest pain (MS hug). Monocytosis could be present due to the inflammatory nature of the disease. Interstitial cystitis could be a related symptom.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.reasoning: Anxiety can manifest with physical symptoms, including chest pain and difficulties with concentration or focusing. Interstitial cystitis and sinus problems can also be exacerbated or influenced by stress and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: An overlap of autoimmune conditions that can include symptoms like chest pain (due to heart and lung involvement), difficulty focusing vision, and potentially include or mimic interstitial cystitis and present with elevated monocytic counts.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to hypotension, angioedema, and in severe cases, hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Neurogenic Shock
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from damage to the nervous system, which can cause hypotension, incontinence, and, in severe cases, hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Cardiogenic Shock
diagnoses.description: A severe cardiac condition that can lead to hypotension, syncope, and hypoxia due to inadequate circulation.

diagnoses.name: Severe Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A widespread infection causing organ failure and hypotension, potentially leading to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Crisis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening condition that occurs when there is insufficient cortisol, characterized by hypotension, in severe cases, leading to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Acute Renal Failure
diagnoses.description: Loss of kidney function can lead to incontinence and, if severe enough, hypotension and hypoxia due to fluid imbalance.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that results in recurrent attacks of severe swelling (angioedema), some cases can lead to hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections, characterized by sudden hypotension, rash, and multiple organ failure potentially leading to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting (syncope) due to a sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure (hypotension), which can lead to temporary hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects the autonomic nerves, which can lead to incontinence, hypotension, and, if severe, potential syncope and hypoxia.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative colitis)
Allergic reaction to drugs or food

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: A demyelinating disease in which the insulating covers of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord are damaged.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, leading to fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.details: A disease that occurs when your blood glucose, also called blood sugar, is too high, which can cause neuropathy leading to numbness.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.details: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, leading to fatigue among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Symptoms can include headache, fatigue, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.details: Can lead to anemia and neurological issues, such as numbness and weakness, due to its role in keeping the body's nerve and blood cells healthy.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Its symptoms depend on the size, type, and location.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.details: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Chronic kidney disease secondary to autoimmune disease
HELLP Syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia and Thrombocytopenia)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia plus Thrombocytopenia)
